title: Mal Hammack
text:
Malcolm Eugene Hammack (June 19, 1933 – July 19, 2004) was an American college and professional <a href="American%20football">football</a> player who was a <a href="running%20back">running back</a> in the <a href="National%20Football%20League">National Football League</a> (NFL) for twelve years during the 1950s and 1960s. Hammack played <a href="college%20football">college football</a> for the <a href="University%20of%20Florida">University of Florida</a>, and thereafter, he played professionally for the Chicago/<a href="St.%20Louis%20Cardinals%20%28NFL%29">St. Louis Cardinals</a> of the NFL.
Early life.
Hammack was born in <a href="Roscoe%2C%20Texas">Roscoe, Texas</a> in 1933. He attended <a href="Roscoe%20Independent%20School%20District">Roscoe High School</a>, where he played for the Roscoe Plowboys high school football team. After graduating from high school, he attended <a href="University%20of%20Texas%20at%20Arlington">Arlington State Junior College</a> in Arlington, Texas, and played football for the <a href="UT%20Arlington%20Mavericks%20football">Arlington State Rebels</a>.
Major college career.
Hammack accepted an athletic scholarship to transfer to the <a href="University%20of%20Florida">University of Florida</a> in Gainesville, Florida, where he played for coach <a href="Bob%20Woodruff%20%28American%20football%29">Bob Woodruff</a>'s <a href="Florida%20Gators%20football">Florida Gators football</a> team in <a href="1953%20Florida%20Gators%20football%20team">1953</a> and <a href="1954%20Florida%20Gators%20football%20team">1954</a>. As a senior in 1954, he was a second-team All-<a href="Southeastern%20Conference">Southeastern Conference</a> (SEC) selection and the first recipient of the Gators' <a href="Fergie%20Ferguson%20Award">Fergie Ferguson Award</a>, recognizing the "senior football player who displays outstanding leadership, character and courage." Woodruff later ranked him as one of the Gators' five best offensive backs of the 1950s.
Hammack returned to Florida to finish his bachelor's degree in 1958, and was later inducted into the <a href="List%20of%20University%20of%20Florida%20Athletic%20Hall%20of%20Fame%20members">University of Florida Athletic Hall of Fame</a> as a "Gator Great."
Professional career.
The <a href="Chicago%20Cardinals%20%28NFL%2C%201920%E2%80%9359%29">Chicago Cardinals</a> selected Hammack in the third round (26th pick overall) in the <a href="1955%20NFL%20Draft">1955 NFL Draft</a>, and he played his entire twelve-year professional career for the Cardinals, in both <a href="Chicago">Chicago</a> (–) and <a href="St.%20Louis">St. Louis</a> (–). Hammack was used primarily as a blocking <a href="fullback%20%28American%20football%29">fullback</a>, but he still had 320 carries for 1,278 yards and seven touchdowns in his career.
